caption.center: ROBERT LEE LATTIMORE, APPELLANT, v. THE STATE OF FLORIDA, APPELLEE.

court.center: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.

opinion.posture: Appeal from Circuit Court, Dade County; James R. Jorgenson, Judge.
opinion.attorneys:
Bennett H. Brummer, Public Defender and Micheal Zelman, Asst. Public Defender, for appellant.
Jim Smith, Atty. Gen. and Paul Mendelson and Joel D. Rosenblatt, Asst. Attys. Gen., for appellee.
opinion.panel: Before HUBBART, C.J., and HENDRY and SCHWARTZ, JJ.
opinion.dissent_text: In my view, the trial judge erred prejudicially in declining to permit counsel to argue to the jury concerning the effect of the prosecution's failure to produce fingerprint evidence at the defendant's burglary trial. See Thomas v. State, 326 So.2d 413 (Fla. 1976); Smith v. State, 365 So.2d 405 (Fla. 3d DCA 1979). Since I cannot agree with the state's claim that, in the context in which the ruling was made, a formal proffer of the contents of the proposed argument was necessary to preserve the issue, seeBrowder v. Da Costa, 91 Fla. 1, 109 So. 448, 451 (1926) (proffer not required when "it plainly appears from the question propounded that the answer . . . would be relevant"), I would therefore reverse for a new trial.Page 260
